Article Title: Adobe brings Gemini 3 Nano Banana Pro to its apps: How to use Google's latest photo AI model in Firefly and Photoshop
Article Text:
How to use Nano Banana Pro in Adobe apps







Adobe has said that it is integrating Google ’s latest image model, Gemini 3 (with Nano Banana Pro), into its flagship creative applications, Adobe Firefly and Photoshop. To encourage adoption, Adobe is offering unlimited image generations using Firefly and all partner models, including Nano Banana Pro, in the Firefly app until December 1 for Creative Cloud Pro and Firefly plan subscribers.The Nano Banana Pro model joins a growing list of partner models from companies like OpenAI, Luma AI, and Ideogram. It has been praised for its significant improvements in editing quality and accuracy. According to Adobe, creators can use text prompts to refine specific parts of an image, adjust aspect ratios and boost resolution.“We’ve been inspired by the incredible work our community created using Gemini Flash Image 2.5 (Nano Banana) in our apps. Google’s latest Nano Banana Pro model delivers significant improvements in editing quality, allowing you to use text prompts to refine specific parts of an image, adjust aspect ratios, boost resolution, and even shift camera angles and lighting,” the company said.It also offers contextual accuracy, excels at generating clean, well-integrated text inside images, including localising visuals with translated text, Adobe said.In Firefly, users can upload up to six reference images and prompt the model to merge and refine those elements into a single, cohesive image.The new model is immediately available across the Adobe creative ecosystem:In Photoshop: Nano Banana Pro is the newest model powering Generative Fill, providing creative professionals with fast, text-prompt-based ways to make specific edits, such as adjusting the lighting of an image from day to night, and generating more realistic, high-resolution content.In Firefly: Creators can access Nano Banana Pro through the Text to Image feature. It is also integrated into Firefly Boards, Adobe's AI-powered collaborative moodboarding surface, where professionals can develop campaign concepts by visualising assets (text, images, icons) in real-world contexts, like a billboard on a city street.
Article Summary: Google’s latest Nano Banana Pro model delivers significant improvements in editing quality. Creators can use text prompts to refine specific parts of an image, adjust aspect ratios, boost resolution, and even shift camera angles and lighting. Adobe is offering unlimited image generations using Firefly and all partner models.

Article Title: Google-parent Alphabet may soon join Apple, Microsoft and Nvidia in $4 Trillion exclusive club
Article Text:
AI reversal and antitrust ruling







Google-parent company Alphabet may soon become a $4 trillion company – only the fourth corporation in history to reach this market capitalisation. The tech giant is riding a rally fueled by artificial intelligence (AI), boosted by an antitrust ruling delivered by a judge, saying the company doesn't need to divest its Chrome browser business. According to a report by news agency Reuters, shares of Alphabet surged more than 5% on Monday (November 24), giving the company a market capitalisation of $3.82 trillion.Notably, the company’s stock has climbed nearly 70% so far this year, significantly outpacing AI rivals like Microsoft and Amazon.com. The exclusive “$4 Trillion Club” has previously included Nvidia, Microsoft and Apple, though only Nvidia and Apple currently maintain that valuation. At the time of writing, Alphabet ($3.62 trillion) even has more market capitalisation than Microsoft ($3.51 trillion).The surge reflects a massive reversal in investor sentiment. After the launch of ChatGPT in 2023, many investors feared Alphabet had lost its AI edge, despite inventing much of the underlying generative AI technology. Alphabet has regained momentum by transforming its cloud business into a key growth driver and receiving strong early reviews for its powerful new Gemini 3 model.The company's recent success also attracted investment from Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway.Furthermore, Google shares have rallied as Big Tech largely emerged unscathed from the bipartisan antitrust push initiated during US President Donald Trump’s first term. The company notably sidestepped a court-ordered breakup after its search business was found to be an illegal monopoly. Notably, Alphabet crossed the $3 trillion mark in September. Analysts further believe that Google is well-positioned in the AI race due to its “full stack” advantage.
Article Summary: Google-parent company Alphabet may soon become a $4 trillion company – only the fourth corporation in history to reach this market capitalisation. The tech giant is riding a rally fueled by artificial intelligence (AI), boosted by an antitrust ruling delivered by a judge. Alphabet’s stock has climbed nearly 70% so far this year, significantly outpacing AI rivals like Microsoft and Amazon.

Article Title: How this Big ‘AI problem’ at Amazon’s cloud computing unit may have helped Google
Article Text:
Lost revenue and client losses

Amazon Web Services (AWS), the world’s leading cloud provider, struggled with “critical capacity constraints” for its flagship AI service, Bedrock, earlier this year which led to the company losing revenue and prompting some high-value customers to shift projects to rivals such as Google Cloud. Citing an internal July document, Business Insider reported the extent of the capacity crunch that it was “threatening customer adoption and potentially causing substantial revenue loss across multiple industries.”The report said that the capacity constraints led to tens of millions of dollars in lost or delayed revenue for AWS. Epic Games reportedly shifted a $10 million Fortnite project to Google Cloud after AWS failed to provide adequate quota for Bedrock. Similarly, Oil trader Vitol risked a $3.5 million revenue hit due to “prolonged quota approvals.”Other large customers, including Atlassian and GovTech Singapore, had at least $52.6 million in projected sales delayed due to waiting on quota increases. Three current and former employees confirmed to the publication that the capacity issue remained a top concern for AWS through September.An Amazon spokesperson confirmed Bedrock is “experiencing rapid growth” and noted that the internal self-criticism is a “feature of our culture, not a flaw.”“At Amazon, we're vocally self-critical because that's how we drive continuous improvement and deliver better results for customers," the spokesperson said in a statement.“This internal candor is a feature of our culture, not a flaw. We're grateful for all customer feedback—including challenges they encounter—because it helps us make Bedrock even better, and that's exactly how you build a scalable, sustainable business that serves customers well over the long term,” the spokesperson added.It is to be noted earlier in this year, Amazon CEO Andy Jassy has repeatedly stressed the intense focus on accelerating cloud infrastructure. For example, during an October earnings call, Jassy confirmed AWS added over 3.8 gigawatts of power over the past year and plans to double its current power capacity again by 2027.He added that the company will remain “very aggressive” in scaling up to meet booming AI demand, believing Bedrock has the potential to grow as large as the highly successful EC2 service.

Article Title: Google CEO Sundar Pichai celebrates new breakthrough in quantum algorithm; Elon Musk replies: ‘Looks like…’
Article Text:
What Sundar Pichai wrote in the post

“New breakthrough quantum algorithm published in @Nature today: Our Willow chip has achieved the first-ever verifiable quantum advantage.

Willow ran the algorithm - which we’ve named Quantum Echoes - 13,000x faster than the best classical algorithm on one of the world's fastest supercomputers. This new algorithm can explain interactions between atoms in a molecule using nuclear magnetic resonance, paving a path towards potential future uses in drug discovery and materials science.

And the result is verifiable, meaning its outcome can be repeated by other quantum computers or confirmed by experiments.

This breakthrough is a significant step toward the first real-world application of quantum computing, and we're excited to see where it leads.”

Why Google’s Willow chip experiment matters

Google To Invest $15 Billion On AI Hub In Visakhapatnam, CEO Sundar Pichai Speaks To PM Modi





Google CEO Sundar Pichai recently shared a post on X, formerly Twitter, announcing a new breakthrough in quantum algorithms. “Our Willow chip has achieved the first-ever verifiable quantum advantage,” Pichai wrote in the post, adding it is “13,000x faster than the best classical algorithm on one of the world's fastest supercomputers”. Pichai’s post caught the attention of Tesla CEO Elon Musk . The tech billionaire replied to Pichai’s post saying “Congrats. Looks like quantum computing is becoming relevant.”Announcing the major breakthrough, Google CEO Sundar Pichai wrote:The achievement marks a historic breakthrough in quantum computing. For the first time ever, a quantum computer has performed a complex, verifiable calculation faster than any supercomputer could — about 13,000 times faster. This moment is being called a “verifiable quantum advantage."Using Google’s Willow quantum chip, researchers ran an advanced algorithm called Quantum Echoes (or OTOC — out-of-order time correlator).This algorithm helps scientists study how information spreads in quantum systems — things like molecules, magnets, or even black holes.The key part: the result was verifiable and repeatable, meaning other quantum computers could confirm it independently.
Article Summary: Google CEO Sundar Pichai recently shared a post on X, formerly Twitter, announcing a new breakthrough in quantum algorithms. Using Google’s Willow quantum chip, researchers ran an advanced algorithm called Quantum Echoes. This algorithm helps scientists study how information spreads in quantum systems like molecules, magnets, or even black holes.

Article Title: ‘Rough news but…’: Netflix shuts down studio behind game that hit number 1 in 26 countries
Article Text:
Netflix shift in gaming strategy







Netflix has shut down the game studio Boss Fight Entertainment, the developer behind the hit mobile game Squid Game: Unleashed. The closure comes as the streaming giant pivots its strategy within its expanding video gaming unit, a report has said.The studio’s co-founder and former CEO, David Rippy, confirmed the closure in a LinkedIn post this week. He said that the studio is “very grateful for the time” it had at Netflix. Read Rippy’s full post on LinkedIn.Hi everyone – well, word has gotten around quickly about Boss Fight’s closure. Thanks, everyone who reached out today. Rough news, for sure, but I’m very grateful for the time we had at Netflix. We worked with some awesome people and made many games that I’m very proud of, including Squid Game Unleased which hit #1 in 26 countries. You’ll see lots of Boss Fighters with similar posts. Please consider them if you have any open roles – they are outstanding people and true professionals through-and-through. As for Bill, Scott and me – we’re going to take a little breather before tackling whatever is next. Love to hear from you if there’s anything interesting going on, workwise or otherwise.Another employee, David Luehmann, a director of game development at the studio, also posted on LinkedIn, saying, "After 10+ great years working at Boss Fight, the last few as part of Netflix, the time has come for the studio to close down."“I am very proud of all the people, work, and games we've released. I wish you could see what we had cooking! There are many talented people that have been impacted by this. If anyone is looking to grow, I'll have many recommendations for you!” he added.Netflix acquired Boss Fight Entertainment in 2022 as part of its effort to diversify revenue streams by building out its video game offerings, news agency Reuters reported.The studio was known for developing two games available on the platform: Netflix Stories and the highly successful Squid Game: Unleashed, which reportedly hit the number one spot in 26 countries.The streaming giant's move follows an earnings call earlier this week where Co-CEO Greg Peters specifically praised Squid Game: Unleashed as an example of the kind of narrative game the company wanted to create based on its original shows.However, the company, which named Alain Tascan as president of games last year, is implementing a new strategy that will focus on four specific categories: party, narrative, kids, and mainstream games, the report added. The studio’s closure signals a realignment of resources toward this updated focus.Despite the shutdown, Boss Fight's two games, Netflix Stories and Squid Game: Unleashed, will continue to be available on the Netflix platform.
Article Summary: Boss Fight Entertainment's co-founder and former CEO, David Rippy, confirmed the closure in a LinkedIn post this week. The studio was known for developing two games available on the platform: Netflix Stories and the highly successful Squid Game: Unleashed. The closure comes as the streaming giant pivots its strategy within its expanding video gaming unit.

Article Title: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang makes another prediction on how AI will change future jobs
Article Text:
File photo: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang (Picture credit: AP)

“If your life becomes more productive and if the things that you’re doing with great difficulty become simpler, it is very likely because you have so many ideas you’ll have more time to pursue things.”

"Everybody’s jobs will be different,”

"I would say that there’s every evidence that we will be more productive and yet still be busier because we have so many ideas. It is my guess that Elon will be busier as a result of AI. I’m going to be busier as a result of AI,”

“The prediction that all radiologists would be the first jobs to go was exactly the opposite.”

AI-Powered Future: Next Gen Careers You Should Watch

What Tesla CEO Elon Musk said about AI’s impact on future jobs at the event





“If you want to work, you know, in the same way, you can go to the store and just buy some vegetables or you could grow vegetables in your backyard.”





Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang said AI's boost to productivity would simply make workers busier, and their companies wouldn't give them more paid time off. According to him, while AI can automate many mundane tasks, the efficiency it affords will not decrease the amount of work; instead, it will free people to pursue a wave of new ideas and unfinished projects. At the recent US-Saudi Investment Forum, sitting alongside Tesla CEO Elon Musk , Huang said:The chief executive of the US-based chipmaking giant also argued that productivity gains will not erase work but it will create more of it. He predicted:a Fortune report noted.Huang added.As an example, Huang cited the field of radiology. He noted:When AI improved image analysis efficiency, it gave workers more time to read additional scans, manage more images, and spend time with patients.This shift led to job growth, countering earlier predictions.While discussing the implications of AI on future jobs, Musk predicted that work could become optional in the near future, as jobs will be seen more like sports or video games. He said:During its recent earnings call, Nvidia, which is a major player in the AI surge, reported strong revenue growth. However, as younger workers grow concerned that AI may replace the early-career roles they rely on, Huang's comments offer a view of how work may evolve. The World Economic Forum estimates that AI could replace 92 million jobs while creating around 170 million new ones.Despite Huang's optimism, the job market is proving challenging to enter for many graduates, as AI is reducing the need for many entry-level positions. Many are turning to advanced degrees, such as MBAs and law programs, as a form of protection.It is not the first time Huang has talked about AI and its impact on productivity. Earlier, he assured people that they should not be scared of losing their jobs to AI, but rather focus on the risk of losing their jobs to those who know how to use AI more effectively.
Article Summary: N Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang said AI's boost to productivity would simply make workers busier, and their companies wouldn't give them more paid time off. According to him, while AI can automate many mundane tasks, the efficiency it affords will not decrease the amount of work; instead, it will free people to pursue a wave of new ideas.

Article Title: Investigate Facebook, Instagram and if… : US senators write letter to FTC and SEC chiefs on scam ads, Meta responds
Article Text:
What are the allegations against Meta



Meta denies claims, says it ‘aggressively fights fraud’







US Senators Josh Hawley and Richard Blumenthal have written a letter to the heads of the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), demanding an immediate investigation into scam ads on Meta-owned Facebook and Instagram, a report has said. News agency Reuters recently reported that the social media giant allegedly earns billions in revenue from running ads on these platforms that promote scams and illicit activities.In a joint letter to the federal agencies, the bipartisan pair stated, “The FTC and SEC should immediately open investigations and, if the reporting is accurate, pursue vigorous enforcement action where appropriate” to compel Meta to disgorge profits, pay penalties, and agree to cease running such advertisements.Citing internal Meta documents from late 2024, which indicated that the company earned approximately 10% of its revenue (around $16 billion) from illicit advertising that year, the senators expressed skepticism regarding Meta’s efforts to combat the issue. One document reportedly noted Meta earns $3.5 billion from “higher risk” scam ads every six months.Both of them pointed to the company’s Ad Library which, they claim, still shows “clearly identifiable advertisements for illicit gambling, payment scams, crypto scams, AI deepfake sex services, and fake offers of federal benefits.”The senators further alleged that Meta’s actions suggest a conscious choice to accept fraudulent ads, noting that the company has “drastically cut its safety staff... even as it dumps unimaginable sums into its generative AI projects.”In response, Meta spokesman Andy Stone asserted that the senators' letter “makes claims that are exaggerated and wrong.”“We aggressively fight fraud and scams because people on our platforms don’t want this content, legitimate advertisers don’t want it and we don’t want it either,” Stone said, noting that Meta had reduced user reports of scams by 58% over the last eighteen months.
Article Summary: US Senators Josh Hawley and Richard Blumenthal have written a letter to the heads of the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) They are demanding an immediate investigation into scam ads on Meta-owned Facebook and Instagram. Meta denies claims, says it ‘aggressively fights fraud’

Article Title: Former GitHub CEO Thomas Dohmke joins AI startup to fix the security flaw he says threatens AI coding tools
Article Text:
Thomas Dohmke, ex-CEO of GitHub

AI Coding tools create new security challenges for enterprises





Thomas Dohmke, who stepped down as GitHub CEO in August, has landed his next role at Apiiro, a startup focused on securing AI-generated code and protecting enterprise software systems from emerging cybersecurity threats, just months after leaving his position as GitHub CEO. The startup helps organisations monitor and secure AI-generated software code and codebases.Dohmke will focus on helping Apiiro develop new protections for AI-generated software code, addressing growing concerns that AI coding tools could make enterprise systems more vulnerable to cyberattacks.Dohmke explained that developers now often use multiple AI coding agents, and these tools don't necessarily know all the policies, rules, and safeguards that their employers have set up to ensure their codebases and broader technology offerings are secure.Apiiro's technology connects with companies' code-management systems, providing this crucial context for AI code generation. The platform can spot and automatically fix issues in code, helping developers comply with company guidelines without creating additional work.Apiiro has raised more than $100 million from investors, including General Catalyst, Greylock, and Kleiner Perkins. CEO Idan Plotnik has previously launched and sold other startups and served as a cybersecurity executive at Microsoft.Dohmke said he met Plotnik about three years ago and was impressed by the CEO's energy and Apiiro's mission. While he receives equity for his advisory role, Dohmke indicated he's more interested in what Apiiro is building than compensation.In August, Dohmke announced his departure from GitHub to pursue entrepreneurial ventures after over a decade at Microsoft. Under his leadership, GitHub Copilot grew to over 20 million users, becoming the leading AI coding assistant in the market.
Article Summary: Thomas Dohmke, who stepped down as GitHub CEO in August, has landed his next role at Apiiro. The startup helps organisations monitor and secure AI-generated software code and codebases.Apiiro has raised more than $100 million from investors, including General Catalyst.

Article Title: Microsoft plans to speed Up Windows 11 File Explorer by keeping it always-on
Article Text:
File Explorer’s background to eliminate launch delays and interface lag

Satya Nadella Steps Back to Focus on AI: Microsoft’s Major Reorganisation Explained





Microsoft has acknowledged persistent performance problems with File Explorer in Windows 11 and announced plans to preload the application in the background to reduce launch delays. The company is testing the feature in Windows 11 Insider Preview Build 26220.7271, available in Dev and Beta channels, with a full rollout expected in early 2026.The performance fix addresses widespread complaints from users who experience delays of over a second when opening File Explorer, often seeing a blank window with "Working on it..." before the interface loads. Unlike Windows 10, where File Explorer launched almost instantly, Windows 11 users have reported consistent slowdowns regardless of hardware specifications.While the Windows shell (explorer.exe) already runs continuously to power the taskbar and desktop, File Explorer itself doesn't remain open in the background. Microsoft's new approach will keep File Explorer preloaded in memory, allowing the interface to appear immediately when users click to open it.The feature will be enabled by default but can be disabled through Folder Options under the View tab by unchecking "Enable window preloading for faster launch times."Microsoft emphasized the change should be invisible to users except for improved performance, with minimal impact on RAM usage based on initial testing.Alongside the performance improvements, Microsoft is redesigning File Explorer's context menu to reduce clutter. A new "Manage file" flyout consolidates options like "Compress to ZIP file" and "Copy as path," while cloud-specific commands have been grouped into individual provider flyouts. The "Open folder location" option has been repositioned next to "Open" for more intuitive access.Microsoft is seeking user feedback through the Feedback Hub under "Files, Folders and Online Storage" as it refines both the preloading feature and interface changes before the wider release.
Article Summary: Microsoft is testing the feature in Windows 11 Insider Preview Build 26220.7271, available in Dev and Beta channels. The company is seeking user feedback through the Feedback Hub under "Files, Folders and Online Storage" as it refines both the preloading feature and interface changes before the wider release.

Article Title: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella is turning to an executive who faced employee complaints of "throwing bombshells into their organisation" 15 years ago
Article Text:
Satya Nadella Steps Back to Focus on AI: Microsoft’s Major Reorganisation Explained

AI era challenges

Harms’ current role



Harms was the director of corporate strategy in 2010.

Now he is working as the corporate vice president under Cloud + AI chief Scott Guthrie and he will continue reporting to him

In the memo shared Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella said that Harms’ “new scope will extend beyond AI Infra”. He will help Microsoft in understanding how existing categories will be transformed and new ones created.





Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella has tapped longtime strategist Rolf Harms to help the tech giant rethink its business model for the era of artificial intelligence, taking lessons from Microsoft’s cloud transformation 15 years ago. As reported by Business Insider, in a memo to top executives issued earlier this month, Nadella said that Microsoft must ‘rapidly rethink the new economics of AI across the company — just as we once did with the cloud.’Harms who co-authored the influential 2010 white paper Economics of the Cloud, which forced a cultural reckoning inside Microsoft and helped justify massive investments in cloud infrastructure. The paper highlighted how customers would eventually be able to save money by adopting large-scale could services despite early concerns about security and reliability. At the time, some employees complained Harms was “throwing bombshells into their org. ” Nadella recalled Harms’ response, “They’re already there, I’m just helping you find them.”Nadella mentioned that the same kind of disruptive mindset is needed today as Microsoft is now facing the mounting questions about whether the aggressive AI infrastructure spending will actually pay off. Earlier this year, Microsoft slowed down its AI investments, but it doubled down with the major new deals with Anthropic and OpenAI.The expanded role of Harm will also include advising Nadella and other senior leadership on how to adapt Microsoft’s economics for AI ranging from infrastructure to platform technology and applications.Microsoft’s cloud reboot was once seen as risky but ultimately reshaped the company’s fortunes. Nadella believes AI requires a similar overhaul, with Harms again playing a pivotal role in guiding the economics of a platform shift that could define the next decade.
Article Summary: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella has tapped longtime strategist Rolf Harms to help the tech giant rethink its business model for the era of artificial intelligence. Article Title: Malaysia proposes social media ban for children under 16 from 2026
Article Text:
Global context on Malaysian social media ban

Malaysian social media ban details





Malaysia has now announced that it is planning to ban the use of social media for children under the age of 16 years starting next year. As reported by Reuters, the Malaysian government is working on to soon join the list of countries that are either tightening rules or are imposing a ban on the use of social media by children. Fahmi Fadzil, the communication minister of Malaysia said that the government is framing a legislation which will make it illegal for the children below 16 years of age to make or maintain a social media account on platforms like Facebook, TikTok, Instagram and Snapchat.Along with this, Fadzil also added that the Malaysian government is taking this step in order to protect young children from online threats such as exploitation, cyberbullying and exposure to inappropriate content.The plan of the Malaysian government to impose a ban on social media comes amid the growing wave of international scrutiny over the impact of social media on children. Recently, the Australian government also announced that it will enforce a social media ban for teen starting December 2025. On the other hand, the lawmakers in the United States and Europe are debating over stricter age-verification files and better parental consent requirements.As reported by Reuters, the Malaysian government said that the ban on social media will be backed by new regulatory powers. The ban will require the social media platforms to implement better age-verification systems. Also, the parents and guardians may also face penalties if they allow underage children to bypass rules and maintain a social media account.Fadzil further added that the government is also working with the tech companies, child welfare groups and educators in order to finalise the framework for the ban before its roll out in 2026.
Article Summary: Malaysia has now announced that it is planning to ban the use of social media for children under the age of 16 years starting next year. The Malaysian government said that the ban on social media will be backed by new regulatory powers. The ban will require the social media platforms to implement better age- verification systems. Also, the parents and guardians may also face penalties if they allow underage children to bypass rules and maintain a social media account.

Article Title: Beyond amnesiac savants: The race to build personalised AI assistants
Article Text:
By: Sheetal Bahl is a Founding Partner at Merak Ventures, an early stage B2B VC fund backing bold founders in AI, DeepTech, and other emerging technologies that might finally give us assistants worth talking to.





It starts small. A slight catch in your voice, a word you stumble over, a quickening of your breath. On their own, these are easy to miss. But together, they could be the precursor to something worse: the spiral of an anxiety attack. (It could also be love at first sight, but no assistant will ever be able to help you with that.)Now imagine an assistant that catches those signals before you do. It hears the strain in your tone, registers the shift in your heart rate from your wearable, recalls that sleepless night, and remembers what happened the last time this strange brew came together. Quietly, it nudges you: take a break, breathe, step outside. And the episode never comes.That is what a PAIA - Personalized AI Assistant - could do. It perceives across modalities, remembers context, reasons over time, and intervenes at the right moment. If this sounds like the stuff of science fiction - Samantha in Her whispering in your ear - it’s because we are inching toward that reality. We’re not there yet, but we’re closer than we ever have been.Today’s assistants are genuinely useful - sometimes indispensable.ChatGPT is by turns a researcher, a friend, and a therapist. Copilots help engineers code faster, note-takers tidy up meetings, wearables nudge us toward healthier habits. These are not gimmicks; they’ve already reshaped how we work and live.And yet, they remain amnesiac savants - brilliant in the moment, but starting from scratch each time. They don’t carry context across conversations, or connect the dots between your calendar, biometrics, and tone of voice. They’re powerful, but fragmented.PAIAs are the next step on this inevitability curve. But to get there, we need breakthroughs - in particular, in what can be called multi-modal, longitudinal reasoning.Multi-modal means taking in different types of input - voice, text, images, biometrics, sensor data - and processing them together, not in silos. Today’s models can juggle formats, but mostly in sequence or in a lightweight fused way. They don’t yet weigh tone, expression, heart rate, and context at the same time to infer what’s happening.Longitudinal means across time. Memory that doesn’t vanish with each session. Pattern recognition that spots the early signs of burnout before every product launch or remembers which client objection has surfaced three times in the past six months. Humans excel at this kind of temporal reasoning; AI is still clumsy.Put them together, they form the gold standard: a system that perceives widely and reasons deeply, across modalities and across time. That’s what would make a PAIA feel less like a tool, and more like a second brain.You might assume that it is a foregone conclusion that the breakthroughs will come from Big Tech - they have the models, the devices, the data, the money. But power and incumbency don’t guarantee leadership in a new paradigm. Microsoft owned PCs but missed mobile. Google owned search but stumbled in social. Facebook dominated social but failed in messaging.In the PAIA arena, there is room for startups to play - in at least three ways. First, the giants build broad solutions; they rarely solve wedge use cases, say, to help sales leaders never forget client promises, or aid therapists to track long-term patient patterns. Second, technical hacks can trump brute force: persistent memory doesn’t mean storing every byte, it means remembering what matters, which is cheaper and more human-like. Third, startups can complement instead of colliding - building assistants that are device- and model-agnostic, surviving in the shadows of giants while carving their own value.Privacy presents perhaps the biggest opportunity to flip the script. "What about my data?" has become the defining question of the category. Big Tech often makes the user the product. Startups can build assistants where privacy becomes the moat, rather than a marketing line. On-device processing, zero-knowledge encryption, federated learning: the architecture can itself become the trust signal.The window of opportunity is narrow - perhaps 12-18 months. And this moment isn’t just for Silicon Valley. Indian startups, with their bias for clever hacks and frugal building, can become real contenders if they play this smartly. The technology has matured enough for everybody to have access to the building blocks, and winning, differentiated plays can still be created before the gates lock.It is rare for Indian tech to have a real shot at building globally relevant businesses during an epochal technology shift. PAIAs offer that chance. Tough, yes. Plausible, definitely. And that is reason enough to chase it.Tony Stark was never really a superhero. Strip away the flying suit and you had a billionaire with terrible impulse control, a flair for sarcasm, and a genius that was as much a liability as an asset. What kept him alive - literally and figuratively - wasn’t just JARVIS, the all-seeing AI in his ear, but Pepper Potts, the all-feeling human who remembered what mattered. JARVIS calculated trajectories; Pepper remembered birthdays. One ran diagnostics; the other soothed egos. Together, they were Stark’s real superpower: an external brain that fused machine precision with human intuition.As for me, I don’t want superpowers - my ambitions are smaller. Just remembering to ask my partner how her doctor’s appointment went would feel like victory.
Article Summary: Sheetal Bahl is a Founding Partner at Merak Ventures, an early stage B2B VC fund backing bold founders in AI, DeepTech, and other emerging technologies that might finally give us assistants worth talking to. He says we're not there yet, but we’re closer than we ever have been.

Article Title: Apple’s next big update for iPhone, iOS 27, may finally bring these features
Article Text:
Engineering teams hunt for bugs in iOS 26

Apple Intelligence remain a key exception to iOS 27’s no-frills approach





Apple has begun work on the next major software releases for the coming year, with iOS 27 reportedly focusing on quality improvements and Apple Intelligence enhancements rather than introducing flashy new features, according to Bloomberg's Mark Gurman.In his Power On newsletter published Sunday, Gurman revealed that Apple is taking a page from its 2009 Mac OS X Snow Leopard playbook—prioritising refinement over revolution. The company's engineering teams are systematically reviewing iOS to eliminate bloat, squash bugs, and boost overall performance following the Liquid Glass design overhaul introduced in iOS 26.Apple engineers are combing through the operating system, hunting for unnecessary code to remove and opportunities to improve quality and performance, Gurman writes. This approach mirrors Snow Leopard's focus on stability after the feature-heavy Leopard release, and comes as users have reported various iOS 26 issues including device overheating, battery drain, keyboard failures, and connectivity problems.The quality-first strategy will also lay groundwork for future hardware innovations, including foldable iPhones and other new devices, according to the Bloomberg report.While iOS 27 emphasises polish, artificial intelligence remains a major priority as Apple works to close the gap with competitors. Planned AI features for next year's release include a health-focused agent tied to a potential Apple Health+ subscription and expanded AI-powered web search capabilities, according to Gurman's newsletter.The update follows the delayed arrival of a redesigned Siri, expected in iOS 26.4 this spring, which will reportedly leverage Google's Gemini technology through a custom implementation for Apple's private cloud computing platform.Apple has also been internally testing a chatbot application called Veritas, though the company currently has no plans to release it as a standalone product, Gurman notes in his newsletter.
Article Summary: Apple has begun work on the next major software releases for the coming year, with iOS 27 reportedly focusing on quality improvements and Apple Intelligence enhancements. The company's engineering teams are systematically reviewing iOS to eliminate bloat, squash bugs, and boost overall performance following the Liquid Glass design overhaul in iOS 26.

Article Title: Snap rolls out bank-linked age checks in Australia; move comes ahead of teen social media ban
Article Text:
Australia’s teen social media ban



Privacy and global implications







Snap, the parent company of Snapchat has started rolling out a new bank-linked age verification tool for its Australian users. As reported by Reuters, Snap has introduced the new age verification tool as the Australian government is preparing to enforce a world-first ban on social media access for children under 16 years of age. As per the Reuters report, starting this week, the Snapchat users in Australia will be prompted to verify their age with the help of ConnectID, a system which is owned by the banks in the country. The ConnectID links a user’s bank account and returns only a yes or no confirmation of age eligibility without sharing the company identity data. Users will also have the option to opt for an alternative verification method. For instance, users can upload their government issued ID card or use k-ID which is a Singapore-based age-assurance provider that estimates age via selfies.Australia’s ban on social media will come into effect starting December 2025. The Australian government is imposing a ban on various social media platforms such as Snapchat, Facebook, TikTok, Instagram. The ban will block the users under the age of 16 years from using the platforms.Australian government also said that the companies who fail to comply with this rule will fact hefty fines under the new law. The social media ban imposed in Australia will roughly affect around 440,000 users aged between 13 go 15 years.If the bank-linked method is use for age verification, then it will be the first time that financial footprints are being used for age assurance in social media. Some privacy advocates have raised concerns about linking banking systems to online playrooms. However, Snap insists that only minimal data will get exchanged. On the other hand, industry analysts suggest that this move by the Australian government could set a precedent for global adoption of age-check infrastructure.
Article Summary: Snap has started rolling out a new bank-linked age verification tool for its Australian users. The ConnectID links a user’s bank account and returns only a yes or no confirmation of age eligibility without sharing the company identity data. The move comes as the Australian government is preparing to enforce a world-first ban on social media access for children under 16 years of age.

Article Title: Reliance Jio, Airtel and Vodafone-Idea have complaint against Apple, Amazon, Cisco, Meta, HP and Intel; tell government that they causing your loss
Article Text:
What telecom operators say on the issue





A coalition of major US technology companies -- including Apple, Amazon, Cisco, Meta, HP, and Intel -- have formally opposed demands by Reliance Jio and Vodafone Idea regarding the allocation of the 6 GHz spectrum band. While the Indian telecom operators are pushing for the spectrum to be auctioned for mobile services (IMT), the tech giants are advocating for the entire band to be delicensed for Wi-Fi use. In a joint submission to the Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) regarding the upcoming spectrum auction, the US tech majors argued that the ecosystem for mobile services in the 6 GHz band is not yet technically or commercially ready. Currently, the Indian government has identified that 400 MHz of frequencies in the 6 GHz band are available for auction, with another 300 MHz expected by 2030. The lower 6 GHz band (5925-6425 MHz) has already been decided for delicensing to support low-power applications like Wi-Fi.The coalition of American technology companies has urged the government to delay any auction timelines for the 6425-6725 MHz and 7025-7125 MHz ranges.In a joint response to telecom regulator Trai's consultation paper for the next round of spectrum auction, the US technology giants have said the technical and commercial readiness in the 6 GHz band is not established for mobile services."We do not recommend setting timelines for any future auction of the 6425-6725 MHz and 7025-7125 MHz ranges for IMT. TRAI, together with the Department of Telecommunications, should review the allocation of the upper 6 GHz band following the outcomes of WRC-27, including Agenda Item 1.7 concerning 7.125-8.4 GHz," the joint submission said. The tech giants said any upper 6 GHz spectrum that would otherwise remain unused should be made available for unlicensed use in the interim. They further suggested that any upper 6 GHz spectrum left unused should be opened for unlicensed use—effectively Wi-Fi—in the interim.The Cellular Operators Association of India (COAI), representing Reliance Jio, Airtel , and Vodafone Idea, has strongly opposed delicensing. They argue that handing the spectrum over to Wi-Fi would result in a loss of exchequer revenue and provide an unfair advantage to foreign OTT players. It said that delicensing even a part of the 6 GHz band will be an irreversible action, permanently foreclosing its use for licensed mobile broadband services and severely limiting India's long-term digital capacity and provision of affordable services."Moreover, unlicensed Wi-Fi deployments by global OTT players and device manufacturers could preclude licensed usage in the band, reduce exchequer revenues and give disproportionate advantage to foreign OTT players, creating an inequitable environment for telecom operators," COAI said.* Reliance Jio has demanded that the entire 1200 MHz of available spectrum in the 6 GHz band be included in the upcoming auction, despite the government’s decision to delicense the lower 500 MHz for low-power applications.* Vodafone Idea has requested that the 400 MHz currently available be put up for sale immediately.* Bharti Airtel, taking a more cautious approach, has sought a deferment of the auction. Airtel cited a lack of ecosystem readiness regarding devices and global harmonization, a view echoed by chipset major Qualcomm.US-based chipset major Qualcomm, however, has echoed views similar to Airtel. Qualcomm aligned partially with Airtel, emphasizing that the upper 6 GHz band is critical for India's future 6G ambitions."By deferring the auction of the 6425-6725 MHz and 7025-7125 MHz bands until after WRC-27, India safeguards its 6G future, aligns with global standards, and honours its leadership aspirations," the San Diego-based Qualcomm said in its submission.
Article Summary: Apple, Amazon, Cisco, Meta, HP, and Intel have formally opposed demands by Reliance Jio and Vodafone Idea regarding the allocation of the 6 GHz spectrum band. The Indian telecom operators are pushing for the spectrum to be auctioned for mobile services. The tech giants are advocating for the entire band to be delicensed for Wi-Fi use.

Article Title: TSMC investigates if the top exec who has joined Intel took TSMC tech; while Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan says: We ...
Article Text:
What Intel said on the allegations







TSMC has reportedly opened an internal investigation to find whether Lo Wen-jen has taken trade secrets with him to Intel without its consent. According to a report in Bloomberg, Taiwanese newspapers spent the week reporting on the transition of Lo Wen-jen, 75, from his retirement from TSMC earlier this year to joining Intel in recent weeks. It is unclear whether TSMC has reached a conclusion about any potential damage to the company, the person added, asking not to be identified since the information is private.“The government is concerned with national security implications,” Taiwan’s Minister of Economic Affairs Kung Ming-hsin told reporters, without elaborating on any of the details pertaining to allegations against Lo. Minister Wu Cheng-wen of Taiwan’s National Science and Technology Council reportedly told reporters later in the day that TSMC is still looking into the situation, according to Taiwan’s official Central News Agency.Lo was responsible for corporate strategy before his retirement from TSMC in July. He was at one point in charge of research and technology development at TSMC and played a key role in facilitating the mass production at TSMC of cutting-edge chips, including those used to make AI accelerators. He is also a laureate of Taiwan’s prestigious Industrial Technology Research Institute.Before he joined TSMC in 2004, Lo spent some time at Intel focusing on advanced technology development, including running a chip factory in Santa Clara, California.He has a doctorate degree in solid state physics and surface chemistry from UC Berkeley.Relations between Intel and TSMC have not been very good over the past few years as the US chipmaker tries to play catchup in the technology race. Intel is at once a customer and a competitor to TSMC, which is also the sole maker of the most high-end chips for Apple and Nvidia.Intel Chief Executive Officer (CEO) Lip-Bu Tan dismissed reports about a new hire taking trade secrets from Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) to his company, saying the US chipmaker respects other firms’ intellectual property. Taiwanese newspapers spent the week reporting on the transition of Lo Wen-jen, 75, from his retirement from TSMC earlier this year to joining Intel in recent weeks. The executive is alleged to have taken proprietary knowhow from his former employer just before his departure. “It’s rumor and speculation. There’s nothing to it. We respect IP,” Tan told Bloomberg News on the sidelines of the Semiconductor Industry Association Awards in San Jose on Thursday. The event recognized TSMC CEO C.C. Wei and former Chairman Mark Liu with its highest honor, the Robert N. Noyce Award.Incidentally, Intel's sacked former CEO Pat Gelsinger frequently argued that it was too risky for the US to depend heavily on TSMC for cutting-edge semiconductors due to growing geopolitical volatility in the Taiwan Strait, creating friction between the two companies.
Article Summary: TSMC has reportedly opened an internal investigation to find whether Lo Wen-jen has taken trade secrets with him to Intel without its consent. Lo was responsible for corporate strategy before his retirement from TSMC in July. He is also a laureate of Taiwan’s prestigious Industrial Technology Research Institute.

Article Title: How Google CEO Sundar Pichai fixed the 'emoji mistake' Google made in 2017 this week
Article Text:
Sundar Pichai (Image credit: BBC interview/ Youtube)

Gemini 3 and Nano Banana Pro

These tools demonstrate improved spatial reasoning, allowing AI to understand how objects should be positioned in the real world.

Tech investor Balaji Srinivasan noted that the burger image showed Gemini 3 had solved a long-standing challenge: “Normally, AI models struggle with spatial orientation… but this image seems to resolve that issue.”

Google’s AI comeback





Eight years after Google was roasted online for a cheeseburger emoji that placed the cheese under the meat. Now, Google CEO Sundar Pichai has finally set the record straight with the help of Google’s latest generative AI models. Back in 2017, Google faced a lot of backlash when the ingredients of its cheeseburger emoji in Android were stacked incorrectly. Pichai jokingly apologised at that time and promised to soon come up with a fix. Recently, the Google CEO delivered the correct emoji. Pichai shared a post on social media platform X (formerly known as Twitter) in which he shared an AI-generated cheeseburger image with the cheese firmly above the patty, captioned “iykyk” as a nod to the viral furor.The emoji correction coincided with Google’s launch of Gemini 3, its most advanced AI model, and Nano Banana Pro, a new image-generation tool capable of producing realistic pictures, diagrams, and charts.The launch of Gemini 3 marks a turning point for Google, which has faced criticism for lagging behind rivals in generative AI. The company’s stock surged to a record high this week, briefly making Google more valuable than Microsoft.Pichai’s decade-long push toward an AI-first strategy is now bearing fruit. “Google really did drop everything they were doing to truly focus on AI,” Srinivasan wrote. “Gemini 3 represents the moment when they actually retook the lead. ”What began as a lighthearted emoji scandal has evolved into a symbol of Google’s AI progress. By fixing the cheeseburger stack, Pichai showcased not just humor but a serious leap in AI’s ability to understand the physical world — a capability that could reshape industries far beyond fast food.
Article Summary: Google CEO Sundar Pichai posted an AI-generated cheeseburger image with the cheese firmly above the patty, captioned ‘iykyk’ The emoji correction coincided with Google’s launch of Gemini 3, its most advanced AI model, and Nano Banana Pro, a new image-generation tool.

Elon Musk

American’s Book Club

Article Title: Meta shut down internal research after finding mental health harm from Facebook, court filing claims: What the company said
Article Text:
‘ Project Mercury ’ findings suppressed



Meta’s Secret AI Army: Top Talent Hired from OpenAI, Google & More

Meta denies allegations, says methodology was flawed







A claim filed in a class-action lawsuit against Meta alleges that the company shut down internal research after finding causal evidence that its products, Facebook , were causing mental health problems to users. The allegation comes from unredacted filings submitted by US school districts suing Meta, Google, TikTok and Snapchat, news agency Reuters reported, adding that the plaintiffs argue the tech giants intentionally concealed internally recognized risks from users, parents and educators.The core of the claim revolves around a 2020 internal research project code-named “Project Mercury.” Meta scientists, working with the survey firm Nielsen, studied the effects of “deactivating” Facebook use. According to internal documents cited in the filing, the results were highly unfavourable: “people who stopped using Facebook for a week reported lower feelings of depression, anxiety, loneliness and social comparison. ”Rather than publicising the findings or continuing the study, the filing alleges Meta terminated further work and internally dismissed the negative results, claiming they were tainted by the existing “media narrative” around the company.One staffer allegedly expressed concern that burying the findings was akin to the tobacco industry “doing research and knowing cigs were bad and then keeping that info to themselves.”In a statement released on Saturday (November 22), Meta spokesman Andy Stone defended the company, asserting that the study was stopped because its methodology was flawed, and that Meta works diligently to improve product safety.“The full record will show that for over a decade, we have listened to parents, researched issues that matter most, and made real changes to protect teens,” Stone said.He noted that the company’s teen safety measures are effective, adding that the company has a policy is to remove accounts as soon as they are flagged.
Article Summary: Claim filed in a class-action lawsuit against Meta alleges that the company shut down internal research after finding causal evidence that its products, Facebook, were causing mental health problems to users. The allegation comes from unredacted filings submitted by US school districts suing Meta, Google, TikTok and Snapchat.

Article Title: Sensitive customer data of America’s biggest banks including JPMorgan and Morgan Stanley may have exposed in vendor hacking
Article Text:
AI generated image for representation

Major financial institutions affected



Sensitive personal data at risk



FBI says it is monitoring situation







Some of America’s largest financial institutions are reportedly working urgently to assess potential damage from a significant cyberattack on SitusAMC, a critical vendor used by hundreds of banks, including JPMorgan Chase, Citibank, and Morgan Stanley, to process real estate loans and mortgages. The New York-based company, which employs approximately 5,000 people and is owned by several private equity firms, confirmed on Saturday (November 22) that it was breached on November 12 and has spent nearly two weeks investigating the scope of compromised data related to residential loan mortgages.Citing five people briefed on the incident, The New York Times reported that JPMorgan Chase, Citibank, and Morgan Stanley are among the institutions notified by SitusAMC that client data may have been stolen. A JPMorgan spokesperson clarified that the bank itself had not been directly hacked.The breach has generated particular alarm on Wall Street due to the nature of information SitusAMC handles. The vendor maintains vast collections of personal data from loan applications, including Social Security numbers and other sensitive financial information.SitusAMC CEO Michael Franco said in a statement that the company has notified law enforcement and “remain[s] focused on analyzing any potentially affected data.”The company has been providing near-daily updates to banking clients as the investigation continues. The company is owned by several private equity firms. It is unclear what data has been stolen, or how many US banking consumers are affected.Meanwhile, FBI Director Kash Patel addressed the incident, stating: “While we are working closely with affected organizations and our partners to understand the extent of potential impact, we have identified no operational impact to banking services.”SitusAMC serves as essential infrastructure for the real estate lending industry, offering services including loan origination, collection, and regulatory compliance.
Article Summary: JPMorgan Chase, Citibank, and Morgan Stanley are among the institutions notified by SitusAMC that client data may have been stolen. The New York-based company, which employs approximately 5,000 people and is owned by several private equity firms, confirmed on Saturday that it was breached on November 12. The vendor maintains vast collections of personal data from loan applications, including Social Security numbers.
